explanations: The French "Cela ne va pas si vite que vous pensez" (That doesn't go as fast as you think) is a declarative statement. The English translation "Don't go so fast" simplifies this into a more direct, imperative-like idiomatic expression, making the philosopher's interruption more concise and conversational.

The French uses the impersonal pronoun 'on' (one) twice. The English translation replaces this with the more concrete 'the Inhabitants of Jupiter' and 'they,' simplifying the abstract agent. Additionally, the French distinction 'nôtre Terre ce n'est pas nous' (our Earth, that is not us / seeing our Earth is not the same as seeing us) is simplified to the more direct consequence 'they cou'd never see us,' streamlining the argument for easier comprehension.

The French 'tout Jupiter se moque de luy' (all Jupiter mocks him) employs a figurative personification where 'Jupiter' represents its inhabitants. The English translation simplifies this by removing the figurative language, instead stating directly that 'he wou'd be laugh'd at and ridicul'd by the rest of the Inhabitants,' making the scenario more literal and less poetic.

The French text includes a relative clause 'qui ont voulu soûtenir que nous êtions' (who wanted to maintain that we existed / that our world was inhabited), detailing the philosophers' argument. The English translation simplifies this complex clause to the concise prepositional phrase 'for this Opinion,' which relies on anaphora, thereby reducing syntactic complexity and making the sentence more direct.

The French 'je croirois plus volontiers' (I would more willingly believe / I would rather believe) conveys a nuanced degree of preference or a softer assertion. The English 'I believe' simplifies this by omitting the comparative 'plus volontiers,' resulting in a more direct and less qualified statement.

The French 'leurs Christophe Colombs' (their Christopher Columbuses) uses a metaphorical plural to signify many explorers like Columbus. The English translation simplifies this by replacing the abstract, plural metaphor with a singular, concrete hypothetical scenario involving 'Christopher Columbus' himself. This change makes the concept less metaphorical and more accessible.

The French 'Il faut que...' (It must be that...) indicates a logical inference or strong supposition. The English translation simplifies this modal expression by presenting the idea as a direct assertion: 'The People ... know not,' removing the explicit layer of deduction. Furthermore, the French 'ne connoissent pas seulement de réputation' (do not know even by reputation) includes the qualifier 'seulement de réputation,' which is omitted in the more direct English 'know not,' simplifying the degree of the described ignorance.

The French text employs the impersonal pronoun 'on' twice (in 'on ne nous voit point' and 'on y voit encore moins'), referring to a general observer. The English translation simplifies this by consistently substituting 'on' with specific agents: 'the Inhabitants of Jupiter' and 'they.' This change makes the subject of perception explicit and less abstract, enhancing readability by using a more direct agent-action structure.

chunks.sourceHtml: P076: Quoy, dit la Marquise, vous comptez cela pour une grâce? Sans doute, répondis-je. Il y a dans tout ce grand Tourbillon seize Planetes. La Nature qui veut nous épargner la peine d'étudier tous leurs mouvemens, ne nous en montre que sept, n'est-ce pas là une assez grande faveur? Mais nous, qui n'en sentons pas le prix, nous faisons si bien que nous attrapons les neuf autres qui avoient êté cachées; aussi en sommes-nous punis par les grands travaux que l'Astronomie demande presentement.
chunks.manualHtml: P056: What, said the Lady Marquiese, do you look upon that as a Favour? Without doubt, said I, Madam, there is in this great Tourbillion or whirling of the Sun, Sixteen Planets. And Nature, who is willing to save us the labour of studying all their Motions, has discover'd to us only seven of them; and is not that a great Favour. But we who are not sensible of this Grace, have so ordered the matter that by our Endeavours we have found out the other nine, which Nature had conceal'd from us, and we are sufficiently punish'd for it, by the great Pains and Labour, which is at present requisite for the Study of Astronomy.
chunks.aiHtml: P056: What, said the Lady Marquiese, do you look upon that as a Favour? Without doubt, said I, Madam, there is in this great Tourbillion or whirling of the Sun, Sixteen Planets. And Nature, who is willing to save us the labour of studying all their Motions, has discover'd to us only seven of them; and is not that a great Favour. But we who are not sensible of this Grace, have so ordered the matter that by our Endeavours we have found out the other nine, which Nature had conceal'd from us, and we are sufficiently punish'd for it, by the great Pains and Labour, which is at present requisite for the Study of Astronomy.
explanations: The translator clarifies the potentially obscure French term "Tourbillon" (referring to Cartesian vortices) by adding the explanatory phrase "or whirling of the Sun." This gloss simplifies the scientific concept by providing an immediate definition, enhancing readability for an audience perhaps unfamiliar with this specific cosmological theory.

The French uses a passive construction `qui avoient êté cachées` (which had been hidden), leaving the agent implicit. The English translation `which Nature had conceal'd from us` makes the agent "Nature" explicit. This change simplifies the original by removing ambiguity about who performed the action of concealing, making the narrative clearer and more direct.

The French `aussi` at the beginning of this clause functions as a consequential conjunction (meaning "and so" or "therefore"). The translation replaces this specific logical marker with the simpler and more general conjunction `and`. This shift simplifies the explicit logical connection, relying more on context.

The original French `que l'Astronomie demande presentement` (that Astronomy demands/requires presently) is concise. The translation expands this to `which is at present requisite for the Study of Astronomy` by adding "for the Study of". This explicitation clarifies that the efforts are for the purpose of studying astronomy, reducing the inferential load on the reader and thereby simplifying the text.

chunks.sourceHtml: P077: Je voy, reprit-elle, par ce nombre de seize Planetes qu'il faut que Saturne ait cinq Lunes. Il les a aussi, répliquay-je, & de ces cinq Lunes, il y en a deux bien fraîchement découvertes; mais il ya a quelque chose qui est encore bien plus remarquable. Comme son année est de trente des nôtres, & que par consequent il a des Pays, où une seule nuit dure quinze ans entiers, devinez ce que la Nature a inventé pour éclaires des nuits si affreuses. Elle ne s'est pas contentée de donner cinq Lunes à Saturne, elle a mis autour de luy un grand Cercle, ou un grand Anneau qui l'environne entierement, & qui êtant assez élevé pour être hors de l'ombre du Corps de cette Planete, refléchit perpetuellement la lumiere du Soleil dans les lieux qui ne le voyent point.
chunks.manualHtml: P057: I see, answer'd she, by the number of sixteen Planets, that Saturn must have five Moons. He has so, said I, Madam, and two of the five are discover'd very lately, but there is yet something more remarkable in that Planet; for his Year is as long as thirty of ours; and consequently there are Climates in that World [translates "des Pays", where one Night lasts for fifteen Years together. Can you guess what Nature has intended for the enlightning of Nights so long and dreadful? She was not satisfied to bestow on Saturn five Moons; but has also given him a great Circle or Ring, which environs him entirely, and which is elevated sufficiently high enough to be out of the shadow of this Planet. It reflects the Light of the Sun perpetually upon the Inhabitants of Saturn, who have the Misfortune to live in that Climate, that is, so long a time depriv'd of the influence of his Beams.

explanations: The French phrase "quelque chose qui est encore bien plus remarquable" (something that is even more remarkable) is general. The English translation adds "in that Planet," specifying what this remarkable thing pertains to. This explication reduces the reader's need for inference, simplifying comprehension by increasing explicitness.

The general French term "des Pays" (countries/lands/regions) is translated as "Climates in that World." This lexical choice narrows the meaning to a concept more directly relevant to planetary science ("Climates") and makes the location explicit ("in that World"), simplifying by reducing the generality of the original term and enhancing contextual relevance for the popular science reader. The provided target text itself includes an editorial note "[translates \"des Pays\"]" immediately after this phrase, highlighting this lexical shift.

The translation changes "inventé" (invented) to "intended," arguably using a more conventional term for Nature's purpose in this context. More clearly, "si affreuses" (so dreadful/frightful) is expanded to "so long and dreadful." This latter addition explicitly links the dreadfulness of the nights to their previously mentioned length, simplifying comprehension by reiterating information and clarifying the cause of the dreadfulness.

The original French uses a single, long participial clause to describe both the ring's position and its reflective function. The translation simplifies this complex structure by effectively splitting it into two main ideas, with the reflective action becoming a new sentence ("It reflects..."). Furthermore, the concise French phrase "refléchit perpetuellement la lumiere du Soleil dans les lieux qui ne le voyent point" (perpetually reflects the sunlight in the places that do not see it [the Sun]) is significantly expanded and explicated in the English. The target specifies the beneficiaries ("upon the Inhabitants of Saturn") and elaborates on their situation ("who have the Misfortune to live in that Climate, that is, so long a time depriv'd of the influence of his Beams"). This structural simplification through sentence splitting, combined with extensive elaboration, makes the original denser statement more accessible by breaking it down and spelling out its implications for the reader.

chunks.sourceHtml: P078: En verité, dit la Marquise, de l'air d'une personne qui rentroit en elle-même avec étonnement, tout cela est d'un grand ordre; il paroît bien que la Nature a eu en veüe les besoins de quelques Etres vivans, & que la distribution des Lunes n'a pas êté faite au hazard. Il n'en est tombé en partage qu'aux Planetes éloignées du Soleil, à la Terre, à Jupiter, à Saturne, car ce n'êtoit pas la peine d'en donner à Vénus & à Mercure, qui ne reçoivent que trop de lumiere, dont les nuits sont fort courtes, & qui les comptent apparemment pour de plus grands bienfaits de la Nature que leurs jours mêmes. Mais attendez, il me semble que Mars, qui est encore plus éloigné du Soleil que la Terre, n'a point de Lune. On ne peut pas vous le dissimuler, répondis-je, il n'en a point, & il faut qu'il ait pour ses nuits des ressources que nous ne savons pas. Vous avez veu des Phosphores, de ces matières liquides ou seches, qui en recevant la lumiere du Soleil, s'en imbibent, & s'en penetrent, & ensuite jettent un assez grand éclat dans l'obscurité. Peut-être Mars a-t-il de grands Rochers fort élevés, qui sont des Phosphores naturels, & qui prennent pendant le jour une provision de lumière qu'ils rendent pendant la nuit. Vous ne sauriez rier que ce ne fût un Spectacle assez agreable, de voir tous ces Rochers s'allumer de toutes parts dé que le Soleil seroit couché, & faire sans aucun art des illuminations magnifiques. Vous savez encore qu'il y a en Amérique des Oiseaux qui sont si lumineux dans les tenebres, qu'on s'en peut servir pour lire. Que savons-nous si Mars n'a point un grand nombre de ces Oiseaux, qui dés que la nuit est venuë, se dispersent de tous côtés, & vont répandre un nouveau jour?
chunks.manualHtml: P058: Well, said the Marquiese, (with the Air of a Person return'd to herself from some great astonishment) all that you say is contriv'd with wonderful Order, and sure Nature has seen and provided for the necessity of some animate Beings; and that the distribution of these Moons, was not a work of Chance, since they are bestowed only upon these Planets, that are at a great distance from the Sun, the Earth, Iupiter and Saturn; for Venus and Mercury have no need on 'em; they enjoy but too much Light already; and their Nights are very short; and it may be the Inhabitants of this Planet esteem Night a greater benefit of Nature, than the Day it self. But hold, said Madam the Marquiese, it seems to me, that Mars, who is farther distant from the Sun than the Earth, ought to have a Moon too. I must confess, said I, Madam, he has none; but certainly, the Inhabitants of that Planet enjoy some other advantage, which supplies that defect. You have seen several bodies —, both liquid and dry, which draw in the Light of the Sun; and afterwards shine and cast a light in the dark. It may be, that there are — great Rocks very high; which are naturally of such a kind of Substance, as to receive great Provision of Light in the Day time from the Sun, which they restore in the Night; and if it be so, you cannot deny, but it must be a very pleasant Scene or Representation, to see all those Rocks from all Quarters begin to shine, as soon as the Sun is down, and make Magnificent Illuminations without Art or Expence. You know also that in America, there are certain Birds, which shine so in the dark; that one may read by their Light, as well as by that of a Candle; and who knows, but there are many of these Birds in the Planet Mars, which fly about and enlighten that World as soon as the Sun is set?

explanations: The formal French interjection "En verité" (In truth) is simplified to the more common and conversational English interjection "Well", enhancing readability.

The French "il paroît bien que" (it is quite apparent that) is simplified to the more direct "sure." The phrase "a eu en veüe" (had in view/considered) is rendered as "has seen and provided for," which makes the meaning more explicit and arguably simpler for the reader to grasp quickly.

The French idiomatic and somewhat passive construction "Il n'en est tombé en partage qu'à" (literally "It has fallen as a share only to") is simplified to the more direct active-like voice "they are bestowed only upon," simplifying the sentence structure.

The French phrase "ce n'êtoit pas la peine d'en donner" (it wasn't worth the trouble/there was no need to give them any) is simplified to the more concise "have no need on 'em," also using more common vocabulary and a colloquial contraction.

The French "ne reçoivent que trop de lumiere" (receive only too much light) uses the restrictive "ne...que." The English "they enjoy but too much Light already" simplifies this structure to a more direct "but too much Light," making it easier to parse.

The French "qui les comptent apparemment pour" (who apparently count/consider them as) is simplified. "Comptent pour" (consider as) is replaced by the more direct "esteem." The adverb "apparemment" (apparently) is rephrased as the modal "it may be," and the implied subject is made explicit ("the Inhabitants"), simplifying the inferential load on the reader.
The formal and impersonal French phrase "On ne peut pas vous le dissimuler" (One cannot hide it from you) is simplified to the more direct, personal, and common English expression "I must confess."

The abstract French "il faut qu'il ait... des ressources que nous ne savons pas" (it is necessary that it has... resources that we do not know) is simplified by making it more concrete and explicit: "the Inhabitants... enjoy some other advantage, which supplies that defect." This reduces abstraction and clarifies the meaning for easier comprehension.
The specific term "Phosphores" is replaced by the more general and common term "several bodies," simplifying the vocabulary for broader accessibility.

The two descriptive French verbs "s'en imbibent" (soak it up) and "s'en penetrent" (are penetrated by it) are condensed and simplified into the more common and singular phrasal verb "draw in," reducing lexical density and complexity.

The phrase "jettent un assez grand éclat" (cast a rather great brightness) is simplified to "shine and cast a light." This uses more common verbs ("shine," "cast a light") and slightly reduces the descriptive intensity of "assez grand éclat," making it more straightforward.

The specific term "Phosphores naturels" (natural phosphors) is replaced by a more descriptive and general phrase "naturally of such a kind of Substance." This simplifies by avoiding a potentially unfamiliar technical term and explaining the concept using more common words.

The French 'Vous ne sauriez [verb] que ce ne fût...' represents a formal and somewhat complex structure for making an assertion. The translation 'you cannot deny, but it must be...' simplifies this structure by using more direct phrasing. This assumes the translator interpreted the source's 'rier' (to laugh) as a likely scribal error for 'nier' (to deny), a verb which fits the context and the rendered translation.

The French "s'allumer" (to light up) is replaced by the more common phrase "begin to shine." Additionally, the conditional/subjunctive mood in "seroit couché" (would be set) is simplified to the indicative "is down," making the expression more direct and easier to understand.

The somewhat more formal adjective "lumineux" (luminous) is replaced by the more common verb "shine," and the formal/poetic noun "les tenebres" (the darkness) is simplified to the common noun "the dark," using more frequent vocabulary.
The French phrase "dés que la nuit est venuë" (as soon as night has come) is simplified to the more concrete and common expression "as soon as the Sun is set."
The descriptive French "se dispersent de tous côtés" (disperse themselves in all directions) is simplified to the more common and concise verb phrase "fly about."
The somewhat metaphorical French "vont répandre un nouveau jour?" (go to spread a new day/light?) is simplified to the more direct and less figurative phrase "enlighten that World."

chunks.sourceHtml:
P079: Je ne me contente, reprit-elle, ny de vos Rochers, ni de vos Oiseaux. Cela ne laisseroit pas d'être joly, mais puis que la Nature a donné tant de Lunes à Saturne & à Jupiter, c'est une marque qu'il faut des Lunes. J'eusse êté bien-aise que tous les Mondes éloignez du Soleil en eussent eu, si Mars ne nous fût point venu faire une exception desagreable. Ah! vraiment, répliquay-je, si vous vous mêliez de Philosophie plus que vous ne faites, il faudroit bien que vous vous accoûtumassiez à voir des exceptions dans les meilleurs Sistêmes. Il y a toûjours quelque chose qui y convient le plus juste du monde, & puis quelque chose aussi qu'on y fait convenir comme on peut, ou qu'on laisse-là, si on desespere d'en pouvoir venir à bout. Usons-en de même pour Mars, puis qu'il ne nous est point favorable, & ne parlons point de luy. Nous serions bien étonnez, si nous êtions dans Saturne, de voir sur nos têtes pendant la nuit ce grand Anneau qui iroit en forme de demiy Cercle d'un bout à l'autre de l'Horizon, & qui nous renvoyant la lumiere du Soleil feroit l'effet d'une Lune continuë. Et ne mettrons-nous point d'Habitans dans ce grand Anneau, interrompit-elle en riant? Quoy que je sois d'humeur, répondis-je, à en envoyer par tout assez hardiment, je vous avoüe que je n'oserois en mettre là, cet Anneau me paroît une Habitation trop irregulière. Pour les cinq petites Lunes, on ne peut pas se dispenser de les peupler. Si cependant l'Anneau n'êtoit, comme quelques-uns le soupçonnent, qu'un Cercle de Lunes qui se suivissent de fort prés, & eussent un mouvement égal, & que les cinq petites Lunes fussent trois échappées de ce grand Cercle, que de Mondes dans le Tourbillon de Saturne! Quoy qu'il en soit, avec le secours même de l'Anneau, les Gens de Saturne sont assez misérables. Il leur donne la lumiere, mais quelle lumiere, dans l'éloignement où il est du Soleil! Le Soleil même n'est pour eux qu'une petite Etoile blanche & pâle, qui n'a qu'un éclat & une chaleur bien foible, & si vous les mettiez dans nos Pays les plus froids, dans le Groënland, ou dans la Laponie, vous les verriez suër à grosses gouttes & expirer de chaud.

P080: Vous me donnez une idée de Saturne qui me gele, dit la Marquise, au lieu que tan tôt vous m'échauffiez en me parlant de Mercure. Il faut bien, répliquay-je, que les deux Mondes qui sont aux extrémitez de ce grand Tourbillon, soient opposées en toutes choses.

P081: Ainsi, reprit-elle, on est bien sage dans Saturne, car vous m'avez dit que tout le monde êtoit fou dans Mercure. Si on n'est pas bien sage dans Saturne, repris- je, du moins, selon toutes les apparences, on y est bien flegmatique. Ce sont Gens qui ne savent ce que c'est que de rire, qui prennent toûjours un jour pour répondre à la moindre question qu'on leur fait, & qui eussent trouvé Caton d'Utique trop badin & trop folâtre..
chunks.manualHtml: P059: Your Rocks, and your flying Birds, said the Marquiese, do not at all satisfie me. I confess such objects wou'd be very pretty; but since Nature has given so many Moons to Saturn and Iupiter; 'tis a sign, that they are absolutely necessary as well to Mars. I shou'd have been glad that all the Worlds distant from the Sun, cou'd have had their Moons; and that Mars might not have been so disagreeably excepted. Oh! Madam, said I, if you think it worth your pains to make any further Progress in Philosophy, you must accustom your self to such Exceptions; in the best Systems, there are always some things that agree exactly; but there are other things, that one must adjust as well as one can, or leave them as they are, if there be no hopes to overcome the difficulty: Let us do so if you please with Mars; and since he is not favourable to us, say no more of him. And tell me if it wou'd not be strangely surprizing, if we were in the World of Saturn, to see above our Heads in the Night that great Ring in the form of a Semi-Circle, going from opposite Points of the Horizon; and which reflecting the Light of the Sun upon us, wou'd have the effect of a continu'd Moon. And shall we place no Inhabitants upon that great Ring, said the Marquiese, laughing? I answer'd her, that (tho in the Humour I was in, I was enclin'd to put Inhabitants every where) I confess, I dare not set any upon so irregular a Habitation; but for the five little Moons, there is no dispensing with them, for they must have Inhabitants. But some do imagine, that this Ring or great Circle is compos'd of Moons join'd very near together, having all an equal Motion, and turning one way, and that the five little Moons I spoke of, had only escaped out of this great Ring; what an Infinity of Worlds are there then in the Tourbillion or whirlings of Saturn? and yet whatever is the Cause, the Inhabitants of Saturn are miserable enough, notwithstanding the Assistance of this great Ring. 'Tis true, it gives them Light, but what kind of Light? Sure a very feeble one at that great distance from the Sun, where she her self appears to 'em, but as a little pale Star, a very faint heat and Light, so that if you wou'd carry some of the Inhabitants of Saturn to our coldest Countries, as Green-Land, or Lap-Land, you wou'd see 'em all of a sweat, and melt away with heat. You give me an Idea of Saturn, said the Marquiese; that makes me shiver with cold; whereas before you warm'd me as much with the descriptions you gave me of Mercury. There is a Necessity, said I, that the two Worlds that are at the extremity of this great Tourbillion, must be contrary one to another in every thing. At that rate, said she, the Inhabitants of Saturn must be very wise; for you told me the Inhabitants of Mercury were down-right mad. If the People of Saturn, said I, be not wise, they are at least in all Appearance so, and are very flegmatick, they know not what it is to laugh; and who take a whole days time at least, to answer the most trifling Question: They wou'd have look'd upon the grave Cato the Censor, as too wild and youthful for their Conversation.

explanations: The French double negative construction 'ny...ni' is simplified by rendering it as the more direct English negative 'do not at all satisfie me,' making the sentence structure more straightforward.

The complex French idiomatic phrase 'Cela ne laisseroit pas d'être joly' (That would not fail to be pretty) is simplified to the more direct 'wou'd be very pretty,' making the expression easier to parse.

The general French statement 'qu'il faut des Lunes' (that moons are needed) is simplified through explicitation. The translation adds 'as well to Mars' and 'absolutely necessary,' making the Marquise's underlying concern and the strength of her conviction clearer and more direct.

The French active construction with a causative nuance, 'venu faire une exception' (come to make an exception/become an exception), is simplified into a more direct passive construction 'might not have been so disagreeably excepted,' reducing structural complexity.

The complex French modal construction 'il faudroit bien que vous vous accoûtumassiez' (it would indeed be necessary that you accustom yourself) is simplified to the more direct 'you must accustom your self,' reducing the formal complexity of the obligation.

The dense French verbal phrase 'si on desespere d'en pouvoir venir à bout' (if one despairs of being able to overcome it/succeed with it) is simplified by using a noun phrase and infinitive, 'if there be no hopes to overcome the difficulty,' making the structure less convoluted.

The original declarative statement 'Nous serions bien étonnez' (We would be very astonished) is simplified by reframing it as a more direct, engaging question 'And tell me if it wou'd not be strangely surprizing'. Additionally, 'd'un bout à l'autre de l'Horizon' (from one end of the horizon to the other) is simplified by the more pictorially explicit 'going from opposite Points of the Horizon,' aiding visualization.

The French phrase 'à en envoyer par tout,' where 'en' is an anaphoric pronoun referring to inhabitants, is simplified by making the object explicit: 'to put Inhabitants every where.' This reduces the reader's cognitive load by not requiring them to track the referent of 'en'.

The concise French 'de les peupler' (to populate them) is simplified through explicitation. The translator adds the clause 'for they must have Inhabitants,' which clearly states the direct implication of 'populating them,' making the meaning more accessible.

The specific detail 'trois échappées' (three [that had] escaped) from the French source is simplified by omitting the number 'trois' (three). The English translation 'had only escaped' reduces the information load presented to the reader.

The general idiomatic French phrase 'Quoy qu'il en soit' (Be that as it may / Whatever the case may be) is simplified by the more explicit English 'and yet whatever is the Cause.' This interprets 'il en' as referring to the cause of the previously discussed phenomena, making the connection clearer for the reader.

The rhetorical question 'mais quelle lumiere!' (but what light!), which implies its poor quality, is simplified by making this implication explicit. The translator adds 'Sure a very feeble one,' directly stating the assessment of the light's quality.

The French verb 'expirer de chaud' (to expire from heat) is simplified by using the more common and vivid idiomatic English expression 'melt away with heat.' Additionally, the French pronoun 'les' (them) is made explicit as 'some of the Inhabitants of Saturn,' clarifying the referent and reducing ambiguity.

The figurative French expression 'qui me gele' (that freezes me) is simplified to the more common and less intense English phrase 'that makes me shiver with cold,' rendering the Marquise's physical reaction in more everyday terms.

The French phrase 'en me parlant de Mercure' (by speaking to me of Mercury) is simplified through explicitation to 'with the descriptions you gave me of Mercury.' This clarifies the means by which the philosopher had previously 'warmed' the Marquise, making the connection more direct.

The French impersonal construction 'on est bien sage' (one is very wise / people are very wise) is simplified by making the subject explicit ('the Inhabitants of Saturn'). Furthermore, changing 'est' (is) to 'must be' makes the deductive nature of the Marquise's statement (signaled by 'Ainsi') more explicit within the main verb.

The French impersonal pronoun 'on' (one/people), used twice, is consistently simplified by being replaced with the explicit 'the People of Saturn' and the anaphoric pronoun 'they.' This repetition of a clear subject makes the sentence easier to follow.

The French construction 'Ce sont Gens qui...' (These are People who...) is simplified to a more direct attributive statement 'they know not...'. This changes a somewhat formal definitional structure into a direct characterization of the previously mentioned 'People of Saturn.'

The reference to 'Caton d'Utique' is changed to 'the grave Cato the Censor.' This alteration could be a form of simplification if 'Cato the Censor' was a more readily recognized figure of 'gravity' for the contemporary English audience, thereby making the intended contrast with 'wild and youthful' (for 'badin & folâtre') more immediately striking. The addition of 'for their Conversation' further explicates the context of their judgment, simplifying the implicature.

chunks.sourceHtml:
P082: Il me vient une pensée, dit-elle. Tous les Habitans de Mercure sont vifs, tous ceux de Saturne sont lents. Parmy nous les uns sont vifs, les autres lents; cela ne viendroit-il point de ce que nôtre Terre étant justement au milieu des autres Mondes, nous participons des extrémitez? Il n'y a point pour les hommes de Caractère fixe & déterminé; les uns sont faits comme les Habitans de Mercure, les autres comme ceux de Saturne, & nous sommes un mélange de toutes les especes qui se trouvent dans les autres Planetes. J'aime assez cette idée, repris- je, nous formons un assemblage si bizarre, qu'on pourroit croire que nous serions ramassez de plusieurs Mondes différents. A ce compte, il est assez commode d'être icy, on y voit tous les autres Mondes en abregé.

P083: Du moins, reprit la Marquise, une commodité fort réelle qu'a nôtre Monde par sa situation, c'est qu'il n'est ny si chaud que celuy de Mercure ou de Venus, ny si froid que celuy de Jupiter ou de Saturne. De plus, nous sommes justement dans un endroit de la Terre où nous ne sentons l'excés ny du chaud ni du froid. En verité si un certain Philosophe rendoit grâce à la Nature d'être Homme, & non pas Bête, Grec, & non pas Barbare, moi je veux luy rendre grâce d'être sur la Planete la plus tempérée de l'Univers, & dans un des lieux les plus temperez de cette Planete. Si vous m'en croyez, Madame, répondis-je, vous luy rendrez grâce d'être jeune & non pas vieille; jeune & belle, & non pas jeune & laide; jeune & belle Françoise, & non pas jeune & belle Italienne. Voila bien d'autres sujets de reconnoissance que ceux que vous tirez de la situation de vôtre Tourbillon, ou de la température de vôtre Pays.

P084: Mon Dieu! répliqua-t-elle, laissez-moy avoir de la reconnaissance sur tout, jusque sur le Tourbillon où je suis placée. La mesure de bonheur qui nous a été donnée, est assez petite; il n'en faut rien perdre, & il est bon d'avoir pour les choses les plus communes, & les moins considérables, un goût qui les mette à profit. Si on ne vouloit que des plaisirs vifs, on en auroit peu, on les attendroit long-temps, & on les payeroit bien. Vous me promettez donc, répliquay-je, que si on vous proposoit de ces plaisirs vifs, vous vous souviendriez des Tourbillons & de moy, & que vous vous borneriez à nous? Ouy, répondit-elle, mais faites que la Philosophie me fournisse toûjours des plaisirs nouveaux. Du moins pour demain, répondis-je, j'espere qu'ils ne vous manqueront pas. J'ai des Etoiles fixes qui passent tout ce que vous avez vu jusqu'icy.
chunks.manualHtml: P060: There is a thought come into my Head, said the Marquiese; all the Inhabitants of Mercury are very lively, and the Inhabitants of Saturn extremely dull: Now upon our Earth, we have a mixture of both, some are very airy, and some as insipid: Does not that proceed from our being situate in the middle, between these two Worlds, that we participate so of the Qualities of both these Extremes; and there is no fixt settled Character of Mankind; some resemble the Inhabitants of Mercury, others of Saturn; and we are a mixture of all the several kinds of People, that inhabit all the other Planets? I like that Idea well enough, said I, we are of such an extravagant Composition, that one wou'd really believe, that we were collected and drawn together from all the other Worlds. And at this rate, 'tis very convenient to live in ours, since here we see an abridgement of all that can be seen in the other Worlds. At least, said the Marquiese, Our World has one real advantage and conveniency, that it is neither so hot as Mercury or Venus, nor so cold as Iupiter and Saturn: And we have the good luck over and above, to be born in a Climate of this Earth, that has neither excess of heat nor cold. And if a certain Philosopher thank'd Nature for being a Man and not a Beast, a Grecian, and not a Barbarian; for my Part, I thank her, that I inhabit the most temperate Planet of the Universe, and the most temperate Climate of that Planet. If you will trust me, said I, Madam, you ought to thank her for being young, and not old, young and handsome, and not young and ugly, young, handsome, and a French Woman, and not a young and handsome Italian. You have abundance of other Reasons of Gratitude, than those of the Situation of your Tourbillion, or the temperate Qualities of your Country. Good God, said she, suffer me to be grateful for every thing; even to the very Tourbillion where I was born: The measure of the Happiness bestow'd upon us, is too little to lose any part of it; and it is good to have such a Sense and Taste of the commonest and most considerable things, as to turn all to our Advantage and Profit. If we shou'd look after no other Pleasure or Satisfaction, than this World afforded, we shou'd enjoy but very few, expect 'em long, and pay dear for 'em. If Philosophy be the Pleasure, you propose, said I, Madam, I have the Boldness to wish, that when you remember the Tourbillions, you wou'd be pleas'd to think of me. Yes, answer'd she, provided you take care your Philosophy furnishes me always with new Pleasures. At least, for to Morrow, answer'd I, I hope you shall not want; for I have the fixed Stars prepared for you, which surpass all you have hitherto heard.

explanations: The French implies a contrast which the speaker is about to elaborate. The English translation simplifies by explicitly stating "we have a mixture of both" upfront, making the subsequent examples of 'airy' and 'insipid' people easier to contextualize as parts of this mixture, thus improving clarity and flow.

The abstract French phrase 'nous participons des extrémitez' (we partake of the extremities) is simplified by explication to 'we participate so of the Qualities of both these Extremes'. Adding 'so' and 'the Qualities of both' makes the nature of this participation more concrete and easier to understand.

The potentially technical or ambiguous term 'especes' (species) is simplified by translating it to the more common and contextually clearer phrase 'several kinds of People.' This uses more common vocabulary and clarifies that 'species' refers to types of intelligent beings, enhancing readability for a general audience.

The concise French 'tous les autres Mondes en abregé' (all the other worlds in abridged form) is simplified by expansion to 'an abridgement of all that can be seen in the other Worlds.' This explication clarifies what 'en abregé' means in this specific context, making the abstract idea more concrete and digestible.

The original French sentence structure, which presents 'une commodité fort réelle' and then defines it using a relative clause ('qu'a nôtre Monde') and a 'c'est que...' construction, is simplified in English. The translation uses a more direct Subject-Verb-Object structure ('Our World has...'), which streamlines the sentence and improves readability by presenting the information more straightforwardly.

The French phrase 'moi je veux luy rendre grâce' (I, I want to give thanks to her/it) includes an explicit expression of volition with 'veux' (want). The English translation 'for my Part, I thank her' simplifies this by omitting the modal of volition, making the statement of gratitude more direct and less mediated by intent.

The French uses a presentational construction 'Voila...' (There are...) followed by a clause 'que ceux que vous tirez de...' (than those that you draw from...). This is simplified in the English translation to a more direct and active statement, 'You have abundance of other Reasons...', which uses a simpler Subject-Verb-Object sentence structure, enhancing directness and readability.

The French presents two distinct clauses: a statement ('est assez petite') and a consecutive moral injunction ('il n'en faut rien perdre'). The English translation simplifies this by integrating the second idea into the first, forming a single, more concise clause: 'is too little to lose any part of it.' This structural simplification improves flow and reduces textual density.

The French 'un goût qui les mette à profit' (a taste that puts them to profit/makes good use of them) is relatively abstract. The English simplifies this by explication: 'as to turn all to our Advantage and Profit.' This expansion clarifies the practical outcome of 'un goût,' making the benefit more explicit and easier for the reader to grasp, thus enhancing readability.

The straightforward French 'J'ai des Etoiles fixes' (I have fixed stars) is rendered as 'I have the fixed Stars prepared for you.' The addition of 'prepared for you' simplifies the delivery by making it more personal and directly engaging in the conversational context. Furthermore, changing 'vu' (seen) to 'heard' simplifies by aligning the sensory verb with the established context of learning through discourse, making the reference clearer.

chunks.sourceHtml:
P086:. La Marquise sentit une vraye impatience de savoir ce que les Etoiles Fixes deviendroient. Seront-elles habitées comme les Planetes me dit-elle? Ne le seront-elles pas? Enfin qu'en ferons-nous? Vous le devineriez peut-être, si vous en aviez bien envie, répondis-je. Les Etoiles Fixes ne sauroient être moins éloignées de la Terre que de quelques cinquante millions de lieuë, & si vous fâchiez un Astronome, il les mettroit encore plus loin. La distance du Soleil à la Planete la plus éloignée, n'est par rapport à la distance du Soleil ou de la Terre aux Etoiles Fixes, & on ne prend pas la peine de la compter. Leur lumière, comme vous voyez, est assez vive & assez éclatante. Si elles la recevoient du Soleil, il faudroit qu'elles la receussent déja bien foible aprés un trajet de cinquante millions de lieuë; il faudroit que par une reflexion qui l'affoibliroit encore beaucoup, elles nous la renvoyassent à cette même distance. Il seroit impossible qu'une lumière, qui auroit essuyé une reflexion, & fait deux fois cinquante millions de lieuë, eût cette force et cette vivacité qu'a celle des Etoiles Fixes. Les voilà donc lumineuses par elles-mêmes, & toutes, en un mot, autant de Soleils.

P087: Ne me trompay-je point, s'écria la Marquise, ou si je vois où vous me voulez mener? M'allez-vous dire: Les Etoiles Fixes sont autant de Soleils, nôtre Soleil est le centre d'un Tourbillon qui tourne autour de luy, pourquoy chaque Etoile Fixe ne sera-t-elle pas aussi le centre d'un Tourbillon qui aura un mouvement autour d'elle? Notre Soleil a des Planetes qu'il éclaire, pourquoy chaque Etoile Fixe n'en aura-t-elle pas aussi qu'elle éclairera? Je n'ay à vous répondre, luy dis- je, que ce que répondit Phedre à Enone, C'est toi qui l'as nommé..

P088: Mais, reprit-elle, voila l'Univers si grand que je m'y perds, je ne sais plus où je suis, je ne suis plus rien. Quoy, tout sera divisé en Tourbillons jettez confusément les uns parmi les autres? Chaque Etoile sera le centre d'un Tourbillon peut-être aussi grand que celuy où nous sommes & Tout cet espace immense qui comprend notre Soleil & nos Planetes, ne sera qu'une petite parcelle de l'Univers? Autant d'espaces pareils que d'Etoiles Fixes?. Cela me confond, me trouble, m'épouvante. Et moi, répondis-je, cela me met à mon aise. Quand le ciel n'étoit que cette voûte bleuë, où les Etoiles êtoient cloüées, l'Univers me paroissoit petit & étroit, je m'y sentois comme oppressé; presentement qu'on a donné infiniment plus d'étenduë & de profondeur à cette voûte, en la partageant en mille & mille Tourbillons, il me semble que je respire avec plus de liberté, & que je suis dans un plus grand air, & assurement l'Univers a toute une autre magnificence. La Nature n'a rien épargné en le produisant, elle a fait une profusion des richesses qui est tout-à-fait digne d'elle. Rien n'est si beau à se representer que ce nombre prodigieux de Tourbillons, dont le milieu est occupé par un Soleil qui fait tourner des Planetes autour de luy. Les Habitans d'une Planete d'un de ces Tourbillons infinis voyent de tous côtés les centres lumineux des Tourbuillons dont ils sont environnez, mais ils n'ont garde d'en voir les Planetes qui n'ayant qu'une lumiere foible, empruntée de leur Soleil, ne la poussent point au delà de leur Monde..

P089: Vous m'offrez, dit-elle, une espece de Perspective si longue, que la veuë n'en peut attraper le bout. Je voy clairement les Habitans de la Terre, ensuite vous me faites voir ceux de la Lune & des autres Planetes de notre Tourbillon assez clairement à la verité, mais moins que ceux de la Terre; aprés eux viennent les Habitans des Planetes des autres Tourbillons. Je vous avoüe qu'ils sont tout-à-fait dans l'enfoncement, & que quelque effort que je fasse pour les voir, je ne les aperçois presque point. Et en effet ne sont-ils pas presque aneantis par l'expression dont vous êtes obligé de vous servir en parlant d'eux? Il faut que vous les appeliez, les Habitans d'une des Planetes, de l'un de ces Tourbillons infinis & Nous mêmes, à qui la même expression convient, avoüez que vous ne sauriez presque plus nous déméler au milieu de tant de Mondes. Pour moy, je commence à voir la Terre si effroyablement petite, que je ne croy pas avoir desormais d'empressement pour aucune chose. Assurément, si on a tant d'ardeur de s'agrandir, si on fait desseins sur desseins, si on se donne tant de peine, c'est que l'on ne connoît pas les Tourbillons.. Je pretends bien que ma paresse profite de mes nouvelles lumieres, & quand on me reprochera mon indolence, je répondrai: Ah! si vous saviez ce que c'est que les Etoiles Fixes! Il faut qu'Alexandre ne l'ait pas su, repliquay-je, car un certain Auteur qui tient que la Lune est habitée, dit fort serieusement qu'il n'êtoit pas possible qu'Aristote ne fût dans une opinion si raisonnable (comment une verité eût-elle échappé à Aristote?). mais qu'il n'en voulut jamais rien dire, de peur de déplaire, à Alexandre, qui eût êté au despoir de voir un Monde qu'il n'eût pas pu conquerir. A plus forte raison lui eût-on fait mystere des Tourbillons, des Etoiles Fixes, quand on les eût connus en ce temps-là; c'eût eté faire trop mal sa Cour que de luy en parler. Pour moy qui les connois, je suis bien fâché de ne pouvoir tirer d'utilité de la connoissance que j'en ay. Ils ne guerissent tout au plus, selon votre raisonnement, que de l'ambition & de l'inquietude, & je n'ay point ces maladies-là. Un peu de foiblesse pour ce qui est beau, voila mon mal, & je ne croy pas que les Tourbillons y puissent rien. Les autres Mondes vous rendent celuy-cy petit, mais ils ne vous gâtent point de beaux yeux, ou une belle bouche, cela vaut toûjours son prix en dépit de tous les Mondes possibles.
chunks.manualHtml: P062: MY Lady Marquiese was very impatient to know what shou'd become of the fix'd Stars. Can they be inhabited as the Planets are, said she to me? or are they not inhabited? what shall we make of 'em? If you wou'd take the Pains, you cou'd not fail to guess, said I, Madam, the fixt Stars cannot be less distant from the Earth, than fifty Millions of Leagues; nay, some Astronomers make the distance yet greater; that between the Sun and the remotest Planet is nothing if compared to the distance between the Sun or Earth, and the fix'd Stars; we do not trouble our selves to number 'em, their Lustre as you see is both clear and bright. If the fix'd Stars, receive their Light from the Sun, it must certainly be very weak and faint before it comes to 'em, having passed through a hundred and fifty Millions of Miles of the Celestial Substance, I spoke of before: Then consider, the fix'd Stars are oblig'd, to reflect this borrow'd Light upon us at the same distance, which Is every fixt Star the Center of a Tourbillion; and it may be full as big as our Sun? Is it possible, that all this Immense space, wherein our Sun and Planets have their Revolution, is nothing but an inconsiderable part of the Universe? And that every fix'd Star must comprehend and govern an equal space with our Sun? This confounds, afflicts, and frightens me. And for my part, said I, it pleases and rejoices me; when I believ'd the Universe to be nothing, but this great Azure Vault of the Heavens, wherein the Stars were placed, as it were so many golden Nails or Studs, the Universe seem'd to me too little and strait; I fansied my self to be confin'd and oppress'd: But now when I am perswaded, that this Azure Vault has a greater depth and a vaster Extent, and that 'tis divided into a thousand and a thousand different Tourbillions or Whirlings, I imagine I am at more Liberty, and breath a freer Air; and the Universe appears to me to be infinitely more Magnificent. Nature has spared nothing in her Production, and hath profusely bestow'd her Treasures upon a glorious Work worthy of her: You can represent nothing so august to your self, as this prodigious Number of Tourbillions, whose Center is possess'd by a Sun, that makes the Planets turn round him. The Inhabitants of the Planets of any of these infinite Tourbillions, see from all sides the enlightned Center of the Tourbillion with which they are inviron'd; but cannot discover the Planets of another, who enjoy but a faint Light, borrow'd from their own Sun, which it does not dart further than its own Sphere or Activity. You show me, said the Marquiese, so vast a Prospect, that my sight cannot reach to the end of it: I see clearly the Inhabitants of our World; and you have plainly presented to my Reason the Inhabitants of the Moon, and other Planets of our Tourbillion or Whirling: After this you tell me of the Inhabitants of the Planets of all the other Tourbillions. I confess, they seem to me to be sunk into so boundless a depth, that whatever force I put upon my Fancy, I cannot comprehend 'em; and indeed you have annihilated 'em by the Expressions you made use of in speaking of 'em and their Inhabitants. You must certainly call 'em the Inhabitants of one of the Planets, of one of these infinite Tourbillions; and what shall become of us in the middle of so many Worlds; since the Title you give to the rest agrees to this of ours? And for my Part, I see the Earth so dreadfully little, that hereafter I shall scorn to be concern'd for any part of it. And I admire why Mankind are so very fond of Power, so earnest after Grandure, laying design upon design, circumventing, betraying, flattering, and poorly lying, and are at all this mighty Pains to grasp a part of a World they neither know nor understand, nor any thing of these mighty Tourbillions: For me, I'll lazily contemn it, and my carelesness shall have this Advantage by my Knowledge, that when any Body shall reproach me with my Poverty, I will with vanity reply, Oh! you do not know what the fix'd Stars are. I do believe, said I, Madam, that Alexander the Great himself did not know: For a certain Author who holds that the Moon is inhabited, says very gravely, that it was impossible, but Aristotle must be of so reasonable an Opinion (for how cou'd such a truth escape so great a Man as Aristotle?) but that he wou'd never say any thing of it for fear of displeasing Alexander; for had he known there had been a World which he cou'd not have conquer'd, it wou'd have reduc'd him to certain Despair. There was yet more Reason to conceal the Tourbillions of the fix'd Stars from him; if they had been known in those Days, he wou'd have made his Court very ill to that great Prince, who shou'd but have mention'd 'em. As for me who know 'em, I am very sorry I can draw no advantage from that Knowledge, which can cure nothing but Ambition and Disquiet, and none of these Diseases trouble me. I confess a kind of Weakness in Love, a kind of frailty for what is delicate and handsom, this is my Distemper, wherein the Tourbillions are not concern'd at all. The infinite Multitude of other Worlds may render this little in your Esteem, but they do not spoil fine Eyes, a pretty Mouth, or make the Charms of Wit ever the less: These will still have their true Value, still bear a price in spight of all the Worlds in the Universe.

explanations: The original French employs a conditional, somewhat humorous turn of phrase ('if you angered an astronomer, he would put them even further'). The English translation simplifies this by presenting it as a more direct statement of fact ('nay, some Astronomers make the distance yet greater'), reducing stylistic complexity and making the idea more straightforward.

The French uses a repeated 'il faudroit que' (it would be necessary that...) construction, creating a formal conditional sequence. The English translation simplifies this structure into more direct statements ('it must certainly be...') and an imperative ('Then consider...'), making the argument easier to follow. The detail about reflection further weakening the light ('qui l'affoibliroit encore beaucoup') is also less explicitly emphasized.

The French source provides the crucial two-sentence conclusion to the philosopher's argument that fixed stars must be self-luminous. The English translation omits this entire conclusion, simplifying the text by removing a key logical step in the scientific explanation, thereby reducing its density. The provided target segment shows the end of the philosopher's preceding sentence and the start of the Marquise's subsequent (unrelated) line, highlighting the point of omission.

The French original has the Marquise begin her excited realization with 'Ne me trompay-je point... ou si je vois où vous me voulez mener?' (Am I not mistaken... or do I see where you are leading me?). The English translation omits this engaging introductory phrase, simplifying the conversational flow and reducing the portrayal of the Marquise's thought process. The target segment is the beginning of her speech in English, which directly starts with her deduction.

The philosopher's witty and learned response in French, which includes a classical allusion to Racine's Phèdre ('C'est toi qui l'as nommé..'), is completely omitted in the English translation. This removal simplifies the text by stripping away a layer of erudition and cultural richness, making the dialogue more direct but less nuanced. The target text shows the end of the Marquise's speech and the beginning of her next lines, between which the philosopher's French response was omitted.

The French phrase 'jettez confusément les uns parmi les autres' offers a vivid image of vortices scattered chaotically. The English translation, while conveying the general idea of multiple tourbillons within the Marquise's speech, omits this specific descriptive element. This simplifies the text by reducing the richness of its imagery. The target segment shows part of the Marquise's speech in English where this imagery is absent.

The French text specifies a decreasing clarity in the Marquise's perception of inhabitants: Earth (clearest), then Moon and planets of our tourbillon ('assez clairement... mais moins que ceux de la Terre' - clearly enough... but less than those of Earth). The English translation simplifies this by stating the philosopher 'plainly presented to my Reason' these inhabitants, omitting the explicit qualification of lesser clarity compared to Earth's inhabitants, thereby removing a nuance of graded perception.

The French 'avoüez que vous ne sauriez presque plus nous déméler au milieu de tant de Mondes' expresses a nuanced concern about humanity losing its distinguishability in the vast cosmos. The English translation simplifies this to a more general and perhaps more conventional existential question, 'what shall become of us...?', losing the specific intellectual point about the difficulty of 'disentangling' or distinguishing humanity.

The French uses an impersonal and somewhat abstract construction: 'c'eût eté faire trop mal sa Cour que de luy en parler' (it would have been to pay one's court very badly to speak to him of them). The English translation simplifies this by using a more concrete structure with a personal subject: 'he wou'd have made his Court very ill... who shou'd but have mention'd 'em,' making the scenario more direct and easier to follow.

The French phrase 'Ils ne guerissent tout au plus, selon votre raisonnement, que de l'ambition & de l'inquietude' includes 'selon votre raisonnement' (according to your reasoning), linking the philosopher's statement directly to the Marquise's preceding thoughts. The English translation omits this qualifying clause, simplifying the sentence by removing the explicit inter-dialogue reference and making the philosopher's observation more self-contained and absolute.

chunks.sourceHtml:
P090: C'est une étrange chose que l'Amour, répondit-elle, en riant; il se sauve de tout, & il n'y a point de Systême qui luy puisse faire de mal. Mais aussi parlez- moi franchement, votre Systême est-il bien vray? Ne me déguisez rien, je vous garderay le secret. Il me semble qu'il n'est appuyé que sur une petite convenance bien legere. Une Etoile Fixe & lumineuse d'elle-même comme le Soleil, par consequent il faut qu'elle soit comme le Soleil, le centre & l'ame d'un Monde, & qu'elle ait ses Planetes qui tournent autour d'elle. Cela est-il d'une necessité bien absoluë? Ecoutez, Madame, répondis-je, puis que nous sommes en humeur de mêler toûjours des folies de galanterie à nos Discours les plus serieux, les raisonnemens de Mathematique sont faits comme l'Amour. Vous ne sauriez accorder si peu de chose à un Amant, que bien tôt aprés il ne faille luy en accorder davantage, & puis encore davantage, & à la fin cela va loin. De même accordez à un Mathematicien le moindre principe, il va vous en tirer une consequence, qu'il faudra que vous luy accordiez aussi, & de cette consequence encore une autre, & malgré vous-même il vous mene si loin, qu'à peine le pouvez vous croire. Ces deux sortes de Gens-là prennent toûjours plus qu'on ne leur donne. Vous convenez que quand deux choses sont semblables en tout ce qui me paroît, je les puis croire aussi semblables en ce qui ne me paroît point, s'il n'y a rien d'ailleurs qui m'en empêche. De là j'ay tiré que la Lune êtoit habitée, parce qu'elle ressemble à la Terre, les autres Planetes, parce qu'elles ressemblent à la Lune. Je trouve que les Etoiles Fixes ressemblent à nôtre Soleil, je leur attribuë tout ce qu'il a. Vous êtes engagée trop avant pour pouvoir reculer, il faut franchir le pas de bonne grâce. Mais, dit-elle, sur le pied de cette ressemblance que vous mettez entre les Etoiles Fixes & nôtre Soleil, il faut que les Gens d'un autre grand Tourbillon ne le voyent que comme une petite Etoile Fixe, qui se montre à eux seulement pendant leurs nuits.

P091: Cela est hors de doute, répondis-je. Nôtre Soleil est si proche de nous en comparaison des Soleils des autres Tourbillons, que sa lumiere doit avoir infiniment plus de force sur nos yeux que la leur. Nous ne voyons donc que luy quand nous le voyons, & il efface tout; mais dans un autre grand Tourbillon c'est un autre Soleil qui y domine, & il efface à son tour le nôtre, qui n'y paroît que pendant les nuits avec le reste des autres Soleils étrangers, c'est-à-dire des Etoiles Fixes. On l'attache avec elles à cette grande voûte du Ciel, & il y fait partie de quelque Ourse, ou de quelque Taureau. Pour les Planetes qui tournent autour de luy, notre Terre, par exemple, comme on ne les voit point de si loin, on n'y songe seulement pas. Ainsi tous les Soleils, sont Soleils de jour pour le Tourbillon où ils sont placez, & Soleils de nuit pour tous les autres Tourbillons. Dans leur Monde, ils sont uniques en leur espece, par tout ailleurs ils ne servent qu'à faire nombre. Ne faut-il pas pourtant, reprit-elle, que les Mondes, malgré cette égalité different en mille choses, car un fond de ressemblance ne laisse de porter des differences infinies?
chunks.manualHtml: P063: It is a strange thing, said the Marquiese laughing, that Love saves himself from all Dangers, and there is no Systeme or Opinion can hurt him: But tell me frankly, are your Systemes certainly true? Do not dissemble, for I promise to keep it secret: I fansie 'tis founded upon a very small bottom, a fix'd Star enlightned of it self, as the Sun is, and therefore it must be a Sun, the Soul and Center of the World having Planets turning round it as that also has. Is this absolutely necessary, says she? I fear, Madam, said I: Since we are always in the humour of mixing some little Gallantries with our most serious Discourses, give me leave to tell you, that Mathematical reasoning is in some things near a-kin to Love; and you cannot allow the smallest Favour to a Lover, but he will soon perswade you to yield another, and after that a little more, and in the end prevails entirely; so if you grant the least Principle to a Mathematician, he will instantly draw a consequence from it, which you must yield also, and from that another, and then a third, and maugre all your Resistance, in a short time, he will lead you so far, that you cannot retreat. These two sorts of Men, The Lover and Philosopher always take more than is given 'em. You must acknowledge that when I see two Objects alike in every thing that I do see, I have Reason to believe them to be also alike in what I see not; for where is the hindrance or difficulty? From thence I have argu'd that the Moon is inhabited because it is like the Earth; that the other Planets are inhabited because they are like the Moon. I find that the fix'd Stars are like our Sun as to what I see; and therefore, I conclude they are Suns, and have Planets turning round about 'em; and every thing else we attribute to our Suns. Now, Madam, you are too far engag'd to retire; and therefore you must generously yield. By this rule of resemblance, said she, which you make betwixt our Sun and the fix'd Stars, the Inhabitants of another Tourbillion, must only see our Sun as a small fix'd Star, which only appears to them, during their Night. Without doubt, said I, Madam, our Sun is so near us, in respect of the Suns of the other Tourbillions, that his Light must have infinitely greater force upon our Sight than the Light of the other Suns; when we see our Sun, we see nothing else, his brightness makes all other things disappear: In another great Tourbillion, where another Sun governs, he in his turn removes and darkens our Sun, which does not appear, but in the Night as a fix'd Star amongst the other strange Suns (that is) fix'd Stars, and our Sun appears to the Inhabitants of that Tourbillion in the great Vault of the Heavens, as a Star of some Constellation, such as the Bear or the Bull: As to the Planets which turn round about him (as our Earth for example) since they cannot see it at so great a distance, they do not so much as think of it, so that all these Suns are Suns by day for the Tourbillion which they govern, and fix'd Stars by Night; for all the other, every one of them is the only one of his kind in his own World; but serve only to make up the Number of fix'd Stars for all the other Worlds. Notwithstanding, said she, of this Equality of Resemblance of the Worlds, yet I cannot believe, but they differ in a thousand things, for likeness upon the main does not hinder infinite little differences.

explanations: The translator simplifies the French by rendering the abstract phrase "une petite convenance bien legere" (a very slight point of analogy/suitability) as the more concrete and common metaphor "a very small bottom" (basis), making the concept more accessible.

This English segment corresponds to the second French sentence listed for the first point. The original French has the Marquise making two distinct statements: her doubt, then the reasoning she finds weak. The translation simplifies the dialogue structure by merging these two utterances. The Marquise's reasoning (this segment) is incorporated directly as an explanation of the "small bottom" mentioned in the previous English segment, making her overall point more compact and arguably easier to follow than the original two-step delivery.

The French phrase "d'une necessité bien absoluë" (of a very absolute necessity) uses a slightly more formal and periphrastic noun construction. The English translation "absolutely necessary" simplifies this to a more direct and common adjectival phrase.

The French "folies de galanterie" (follies/ extravagances of gallantry) is translated as "some little Gallantries." The addition of "little" and the choice of "Gallantries" (even as a cognate) tones down the intensity and potential extravagance implied by "folies," simplifying the original's somewhat stronger and more literary phrasing into a milder, more common expression.

The French "Vous ne sauriez accorder" (a polite conditional, lit. 'you would not know how to grant') is simplified to the more direct "you cannot allow." More significantly, the complex subordinate clause "que bien tôt aprés il ne faille luy en accorder davantage" (that soon after it isn't necessary that one not grant him more, implying one must grant more, using impersonal 'falloir' + subjunctive) is greatly simplified to an active, direct statement: "but he will soon perswade you to yield another," which avoids the impersonal verb, subjunctive mood, and double negation logic.

The French phrase "qu'il faudra que vous luy accordiez aussi" (that it will be necessary that you grant him also), which uses the future tense of the impersonal verb 'falloir' plus a subjunctive, is simplified to the more direct English modal construction "which you must yield also." This change avoids the impersonal verb and subjunctive mood, making the sentence structure simpler and the obligation more direct.

The original French presents a conditional proviso: "s'il n'y a rien d'ailleurs qui m'en empêche" (if there is nothing, moreover, that prevents me from it). The translation replaces this with a rhetorical question, "for where is the hindrance or difficulty?", which asserts that no such hindrance exists. This simplifies the logical structure by removing the conditional aspect and making the argument's progression more assertive and less nuanced.

The concise French phrase "je leur attribuë tout ce qu'il a" (I attribute to them all that it [the Sun] has) is significantly expanded in the English translation. The target text spells out the implications of "tout ce qu'il a" by stating: "they are Suns, and have Planets turning round about 'em; and every thing else we attribute to our Suns." This explicitation simplifies the reader's task of inference by making the philosopher's conclusions detailed and unambiguous.

The French "il faut franchir le pas de bonne grâce" (it is necessary to take the step/cross the threshold with good grace) uses the somewhat metaphorical phrase "franchir le pas" and the impersonal "il faut." The English translation simplifies this to "you must generously yield." This uses the more direct verb "yield," fitting an argumentative context, and changes the impersonal "il faut" to the personal "you must," making the injunction clearer and more straightforward.

The French uses the general term "les Gens" (the People) and a complex grammatical construction "il faut que... ne le voyent que comme" (it is necessary that... see it only as), involving the impersonal 'falloir que' + subjunctive + 'ne...que' for 'only'. The translation simplifies this by using the more specific "the Inhabitants" and the more direct modal construction "must only see," which avoids the impersonal verb and subjunctive mood.

The French uses the pronoun "que la leur" (than theirs), referring back to 'lumiere' (light). The English translation "than the Light of the other Suns" simplifies comprehension by explicitly restating "the Light" instead of using a pronoun. This reduces the cognitive load on the reader by making the referent explicit.

The French "Nous ne voyons donc que luy" (We therefore see only it) is simplified to "we see nothing else," a common and direct English equivalent for the 'ne...que' (only) construction; the logical connector "donc" (therefore) is also omitted, streamlining the sentence. Furthermore, the concise French "il efface tout" (it effaces/erases everything) is expanded to "his brightness makes all other things disappear." This explicitation clarifies the cause (brightness) and the effect (disappear), simplifying comprehension by making the process more descriptive.

The single French verb "efface" (effaces/blots out/erases) is translated as the two-verb phrase "removes and darkens." This expansion breaks down the general concept of "effacing" into two more specific and concrete actions, making the sun's effect on other celestial bodies more explicit and arguably easier to visualize, thus simplifying the original's more condensed expression.

The French uses an impersonal construction "On l'attache" (One attaches it) and the phrase "il y fait partie de quelque Ourse..." (it there makes part of some Bear...). The translation simplifies this by using a more direct and active description: "our Sun appears to the Inhabitants of that Tourbillion... as a Star of some Constellation, such as the Bear..." This clarifies the agent of perception (Inhabitants, added for clarity), changes the metaphorical "attaches" to the perceptual "appears," and explicates "fait partie de" (makes part of) as being "a Star of some Constellation," simplifying comprehension by making implicit meanings explicit.

The French text uses the impersonal pronoun "on" twice: "on ne les voit point" (one does not see them at all) and "on n'y songe seulement pas" (one doesn't even think about it/them). The English translation simplifies these constructions by using the personal pronoun "they" (referring to the inhabitants of other worlds): "they cannot see it" and "they do not so much as think of it." This makes the agent clearer and the sentence structure more direct.

The translation simplifies by explicitating key terms and merging sentence structures for clarity. Specifically, "Soleils de nuit" (Suns by night) is clarified to "fix'd Stars by Night," preventing potential misinterpretation. The passive "où ils sont placez" (where they are placed) becomes the more active and descriptive "which they govern." Most notably, the vague French phrase "ils ne servent qu'à faire nombre" (they only serve to make up numbers/fill out the count) is rendered as the much more explicit "serve only to make up the Number of fix'd Stars for all the other Worlds." This makes the function of these distant suns significantly clearer. The two distinct French sentences are also woven into a single, more continuous English sentence.

The complex French interrogative "Ne faut-il pas pourtant... que les Mondes... different" (Must it not however be that the Worlds... differ), which employs the impersonal verb 'falloir que' and the subjunctive mood, is simplified to a more direct, personal expression of conviction: "yet I cannot believe, but they differ." Additionally, the French "differences infinies" (infinite differences) is rendered as "infinite little differences"; the addition of "little" tones down the scale of "infinies," arguably making the concept less abstract or overwhelming and thus simpler to grasp.

chunks.sourceHtml: P092: Assurément, repris-je, mais la difficulté est de deviner. Que say-je? Un Tourbillon a plus de Planetes qui tournent autour de son Soleil, un autre en a moins. Dans l'un il y a des Planetes subalternes, qui tournent autour de Planetes plus grandes; dans l'autre il n'y en a point. Icy elles sont toutes ramassées autour de leur Soleil, & font comme un petit peloton, au-delà duquel s'étend un grand espace vide, qui va jusqu'aux Tourbillons voisins; ailleurs elles prennent leur cours vers les extrémitez du Tourbillon & laissent le milieu vide. Je ne doute pas même qu'il ne puisse y avoir quelques Tourbillons deserts, & sans Planetes, d'autres dont le Soleil, n'êtant pas justement au centre, ait un veritable mouvement, & emporte ses Planetes avec soy; d'autres dont les Planetes s'élèvent ou s'abaissent à l'égard de leur Soleil par le changement de l'équilibre qui les tient suspenduës. Enfin, que voudriez-vous? En voila bien assez pour un homme qui n'est jamais sorty de son Tourbillon.
chunks.manualHtml: P064: Most certainly, said I; but the difficulty will be, to find out those Differences. What do I know but in one Tourbillion, there are more Planets turning round it than in another? In one there are Inferior Planets turning round the greater, in another there are none at all: In one Tourbillion the Planets are gather'd together, as it were a little Party, round their Sun, and beyond them a vast Vacuity, extending to the next Tourbillion; in another, the Planets take their Course towards the Extremity of their Tourbillion, and leave a Void in the middle, and I do not doubt but there are Tourbillions destitute of Planets; and others, where their Sun is not plac'd in the middle, and yet has a free Motion, and carries his Planets round with him; others, where the Planets rise and fall in respect of their Sun, according to the Changes of the Counterpoise which balances 'em. What wou'd you have, Madam? Have not I said enough for a Man that was never out of his own Tourbillion?
